postsData.content:
What industrial automation did on the plant floor starting in the early '80s is happening now in dev rooms across the world. And thatâ€™s not a bad thing.

Donâ€™t confuse "elite" with "experienced." They are often not the same. Elite engineers are not necessarily the senior engineers. The middle producers of all levels of experience....the average software developer....the ones more commonly referred to as the 0.1x developers. Those jobs are going away fast. And it's not a bad thing.

Elite engineers will thrive. AI doesnâ€™t replace themâ€”it multiplies their impact. With more leverage than ever, theyâ€™ll build bigger, faster, and smarter. The wheels of progress donâ€™t stop turning.

The future belongs to those who embrace it. Adapt, evolve, and find new ways to create valueâ€”because the shift isnâ€™t coming. Itâ€™s already here.

I had the honor of joining the Karen Medina Super SMART Women Podcast. Who doesn't want to be considered super SMART?!

We also dove into a topic that affects a lot of business owners (and parents in general): work/life balanceâ€”or should I say, the myth of it. As a mom of four, entrepreneur, and someone who thrives on a packed calendar, Iâ€™ve learned that balance isnâ€™t about juggling everything perfectly at once. Instead, itâ€™s about seasonsâ€”knowing where to put my focus at any given time and being fully present in that moment. Sometimes itâ€™s all about my businesses; other times, itâ€™s all about my girls. And letâ€™s be realâ€¦ sometimes, itâ€™s just about finding five minutes to drink my coffee while itâ€™s still hot. ï¸

postsData.name:
Neil Sarkar
Neil Sarkar
postsData.content:
SaaS growth is all sunshine and ARR milestones on LinkedIn.


But behind the scenes? Itâ€™s mostly duct tape, existential crises, and a slow march toward burnout.

Everyone flexes about their latest funding round. No one talks about:
 The burn rate that could set off fire alarms.
 Churn rates that make you wonder if customers are allergic to your product.
 Feature creep that turns your once-sleek SaaS into Frankensteinâ€™s monster.

Since I apparently enjoy self-inflicted pain, I started Clientellâ€”where we build AI agents to help companies actually manage their salesforce instead of drowning in admin work. And let me tell you, scaling a SaaS company is NOT for the weak.

Letâ€™s break down the ugly truths:
â€ 1. Growth â‰  Profitability (But VCs Donâ€™t Care)
Investors love ARRâ€”until they realize youâ€™re spending $5 to acquire every $1. But hey, just raise another round, right? Problem solved.

 2. Churn: The SaaS Version of a Horror Movie
Founders celebrate new ARR like itâ€™s free money. Meanwhile, customers are ghosting them faster than a bad Tinder date.

 3. Feature Creep: When Your Product Becomes a Swiss Army Knife of Doom
It starts with â€œCan you just add this one little thing?â€ Next thing you know, your UI looks like NASAâ€™s mission control, and no oneâ€”not even your engineersâ€”understands what your product does anymore.

 4. Hiring Too Fast, Firing Too Slow
Step 1: Raise funding.
Step 2: Hire like you're building the Avengers.
Step 3: Realize your burn rate is insane.
Step 4: Layoffs. (But make sure to post a heartfelt LinkedIn update about it.)

 5. Losing Touch with Customers
Early-stage? You know every user by name. Later-stage? Support tickets get buried under 5 layers of "escalations", and customers start plotting their escape.

ðŸ†˜ 6. Support is Treated Like a Cost Center (Until Customers Revolt)
Slow response times. Automated â€œWeâ€™ll get back to youâ€ emails. A help center thatâ€™s about as useful as a screen door on a submarine. Shocking that customers leave, huh?

 7. Founder Burnout is a Feature, Not a Bug
Scaling isnâ€™t just â€œhard.â€ Itâ€™s the business version of running a marathon while being chased by wolves.

 TAKEAWAY:
SaaS growth at all costs is just a fancy way of saying â€œWeâ€™ll figure it out later.â€ And â€œlaterâ€ usually means layoffs, panic pivots, or a surprise existential crisis.

Have a SaaS horror story? Drop it in the comments. Or just tell me Iâ€™m wrongâ€”either way, I promise I wonâ€™t ghost you.
postsData.commentAdded: Love your candid insights! Scaling a SaaS is definitely a wild ride. Real talk: lets prioritize sustainability over just chasing numbers! ðŸš€

 Or that inclusive AI models reduce bias by up to 40%?

postsData.name:
Cristina Grancea
Cristina Grancea
postsData.content:
7 mindset traps that keep you playing small:

(And how to reframe them.)

When you start seeing thoughts for what they are,
they stop controlling how you feel.

The good news?
You can break free.

It starts with reframing the way you think:

1ï¸âƒ£ The â€œshouldsâ€ â†’ Anger

Original Thought: "They should respect me!"
â†³ Reframe: "I canâ€™t control others, but I can set boundaries and communicate my needs clearly."

2ï¸âƒ£ The â€œwhat ifsâ€ â†’ Anxiety

Original Thought: "What if I fail?"
â†³ Reframe: "Iâ€™ve handled challenges before, and Iâ€™ll figure this out too. Even if things go wrong, I can learn from it."

3ï¸âƒ£ The â€œI should haveâ€¦â€ â†’ Guilt

Original Thought: "I should have done more."
â†³ Reframe: "I did my best with the knowledge and resources I had at the time. I can learn and improve going forward."

4ï¸âƒ£ The â€œI am notâ€¦â€ â†’ Shame

Original Thought: "I am not good enough."
â†³ Reframe: "I am a work in progress, just like everyone else. My worth isnâ€™t defined by one moment or mistake."

5ï¸âƒ£ The â€œI have lostâ€¦â€ â†’ Sadness

Original Thought: "Things will never be the same."
â†³ Reframe: "Change is painful, but it also brings new opportunities for growth and connection."

6ï¸âƒ£ The â€œthey have what I wantâ€¦â€ â†’ Jealousy

Original Thought: "Why do they get that and I donâ€™t?"
â†³ Reframe: "Their success doesnâ€™t take away from mine. I can learn from them and focus on my own path."

7ï¸âƒ£ The â€œitâ€™s not fairâ€¦â€ â†’ Frustration

Original Thought: "This shouldnâ€™t be happening to me!"
â†³ Reframe: "Life isnâ€™t always fair, but I can choose how I respond. How can I turn this challenge into an opportunity?"

Your thoughts can be your greatest ally, or your biggest enemy.
The key is awareness.

The moment you recognize a thought trap, you take back control.
And when you shift your perspective, you shift your entire life.

- - -

P.S. Which of these thought traps do you relate to the most?

ï¸ Repost to help others in your network
 Followfor leadership, entrepreneurship and aging care insights

comments.commentText: Respect is built through clarity, confidence, and how well you make others feel heard. The best leaders donâ€™t just talkâ€”they connect.

postsData.commentAdded: Such powerful insights! Mindset shifts can truly transform our lives. Which reframe will you embrace today? #GrowthMindset

postsData.name:
Alex Turnbull
Alex Turnbull
postsData.content:
I turned down every VC check for 12 years to keep 92% ownership of Groove. It has proven to be the best decision of my life.

Here's the math:

While VCs are pushing founders to split ownership down to 5% chasing unicorn dreams, independent founders are quietly building $5M ARR businesses they own 92%+ of.

I've seen both sides. And here's the math nobody talks about:

VC Path:

- Give up 95% ownership
- Split decision making
- Lose control of vision
- Raise endless rounds
- Hope for unicorn exit
- Maybe get $50M
- If you're lucky (<1% chance)

Independence Path:

- Build with customer money
- Keep 92% ownership
- Run profitable (50% EBITDA)
- $5M ARR
- $2.5M/year in your pocket
- Complete control always there
- Freedom to choose direction

Thesis: Simple math of a $5M boostrapped ARR beats the promised story of a unicorn exit. The reason?

1. it's achievable (many have done it)
2. it's profitable (50% EBITDA)
3. it's yours (no board approval)
4. it gives options:
- work your way or their way
- sell for $30M or scale to $100M
- take profits or reinvest everything

We've built Groove this way:

- clear focus: sustainable SaaS $5M-$10M ARR
- real moats: ownership, profit, control
- actual freedom: every decision is ours

VCs sell you unicorn dreams

But bootstrappers are building generational wealth

The real win isn't a unicorn exit.

It's complete freedom with generational wealth.

That's why 92% ownership is the new standard.

Let VCs chase their 1% dreams.

Smart founders are choosing 92% of something real.

Build for freedom, not exits.

comments.commentText: The bootstrapped route with higher ownership offers much more stability and freedom in the long run. I love the focus on building something sustainable, profitable, and in your complete control. Itâ€™s a reminder that success doesnâ€™t always need to come with the pressure of chasing a unicorn.

postsData.commentAdded: Incredible perspective! Itâ€™s refreshing to see the emphasis on sustainable growth and independence. Hereâ€™s to building real value and freedom!

postsData.name:
Eli Weber
Eli Weber
postsData.content:
Letâ€™s talk about language. 

The words we use help us express ourselves. And yeah, sometimes that means using strong language 

A lot of people get uncomfortable with "bad words," but language is meant to express emotion. When someone drops an f-bomb in the middle of a story, itâ€™s usually not just for shock value. Itâ€™s because theyâ€™re feeling something deep, intense, and real.

Iâ€™ve seen it over and overâ€”people in professional settings using strong language in conversations, business deals, even in high-stakes moments. Why? Because sometimes, no "proper" word carries the same punch.

At the end of the day, language is a tool. Use it wisely, use it authentically, and donâ€™t be afraid to let it hit where it needs to 

What do you thinkâ€”are strong words just bad language, or do they actually add emotional impact?

t

comments.commentText: I'll out myself-- I use it when it adds impact because I don't want my clients to censor themselves. I value real over polite. But if I think it'll be off-putting to the client, I won't use it. Coaching is the clientâ€™s space, and I work from where they are.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Strong language can convey genuine emotion and intensity, making our messages more impactful. Authenticity matters!

postsData.name:
Terence Huijgen
Terence Huijgen
postsData.content:
Great to connect with builders, marketers, founders yesterday @ SaaStock Amsterdam.

Here are the 5 key takeaways i've learned for a better product growth and online presence as a company or an individual.

1ï¸âƒ£ Double down on your ideal customer profile. Be where they are and focus on marketing, sales, and developing new features for the people who actually need your product. Thanks for this insight;)

2ï¸âƒ£ Marketing and sales are a multichannel effort. This is whattold me. Attend events, publish valuable articles, and host webinars. Decisions are no longer made in a single interaction.

3ï¸âƒ£ Want to grow your network? Don't sell yourself, be valuable to a community of people. Post articles and share insights that truly resonate with your (ICP) audience.

4ï¸âƒ£ Don't create yet another AI wrapper. AI tools can help you validate your business idea in the market, so use them wisely, but build something that isnâ€™t easy to copy. Nowadays, anyone can create something around ChatGPT.

5ï¸âƒ£ Automatic outreach is dead. A few years ago, people thought they could get customers through automatic outreach. Now, LinkedIn is just a bunch of bots liking each other's stuff. Focus on real interactions. Go to events, talk with the right people, and ask them how you can help them.

Thanks,,,,,,,,, and others I forgot to mention for the great conversations!

comments.commentText: The third takeaway is a solid point, Terence Huijgen. Providing value first calls your ICP to you. It's like the Pied Piper, but for marketing.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! ðŸ’¡ Focusing on genuine connections and understanding your audience can truly drive growth. Looking forward to your next steps!
